awd_titl_txt: Exploring submarine slope failures with seismic data and physical laboratory experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
Submarine slope failures occur on margins worldwide and can lead to damaging tsunamis both locally and on distant shores. Geophysical data (bathymetric and seismic) from passive continental margins document that these failures range from thin (less than 1 m) to thick (greater than 100 m) units, may have moved 100s of km, and can behave like a fluid or a solid. These analyses combined with numerical models of submarine slope failures suggest the failures are triggered when shallowly buried sediments are perturbed by an external stress such as a change in fluid pressure or earthquake-related shaking. Existing borehole samples and geophysical data provide a snapshot of what the materials look like after failure and numerical models provide predictions of how failures started, yet there is a lack of direct observations of the failure process which affects the final deposits. This project will characterize failure deposits offshore North Carolina using existing data from the North American Margin Community Seismic Experiment. A scaled, physical model with a novel triggering mechanism will be built to create and visualize failure dynamics. The project will advance process-based modeling techniques to incorporate how initial conditions, initiation mechanism, and failure behavior are linked. As part of the broader impacts a graduate student will be trained across multiple disciplines (seismology, sedimentology, geomechanics and engineering) as part of this project. Overall, the project will contribute to society by improving risk assessment for slope failures and tsunami generation along the US coastline. 

This project will integrate existing field data from the GeoPRISMS-funded Eastern North American Margin Community Seismic Experiment with laboratory and numerical models allowing for a process-based analysis of slope failures that links failure type and dynamics to initial conditions and driving mechanisms including earthquake shaking and fluid pressure changes. Laboratory experiments will provide a control on initial conditions (sediment type and properties), fluid pressures (magnitudes and distribution), and earthquake sources (location and energy) while initiating slope failures and observing failure dynamics. Numerical models will simulate the processes observed in nature and provide a means to link lab-scale experiments with field-scale observations. The project will address the following hypotheses: 1) differences between seismic velocity profiles within submarine slope failure deposits and adjacent, unfailed deposits record different effective stress and strength profiles; 2) effective stress and strength of sediments at the onset of failure impact the slope failure type and mobilization behavior of failed submarine sediments; and 3) slope failure trigger mechanism impacts slope failure dynamics and evolution, which influences their tsunami-generating potential. The overall project objective is to describe and characterize links between failure type, deposits, initial conditions, and driving mechanisms, which will increase the ability to use slope failure deposits in the sedimentary record to evaluate driving mechanisms. This will improve our ability to understand the history and distribution of slope failures and their tsunami potential. The project will also provide constraints on conditions that may produce large tsunami, which can inform risk assessment for slope failure and associated tsunami hazard.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Remobilization of sea floor sediments, or submarine slope failures, presents a hazard to coastlines and coastal communities through the ability to damage seafloor infrastructure and generate tsunamis. Submarine slope failures and the mass transport deposits they produce have been studied across the globe on active and passive continental margins. One interesting observation is that some of the largest submarine slope failures have been mobilized on slopes less than 2?. Despite the global presence submarine slope failures and the hazards they can create, we lack a detailed understanding of mechanisms that link slope failure initiation, evolution, and tsunamigenic potential.

To extend our processed-based understanding of slope failure initiation and evolution and how they relate to tsunamigenesis, we used benchtop flume experiments, field-based geotechnical data, and numerical models. We developed a novel and reproducible approach for benchtop flume experiments to improve our overall understanding of slope response to overpressure (defined as pressure above normal, hydrostatic conditions) using combinations of fine-grained sand (quartz), cohesive clay-sized particles (smectite), and non-cohesive clay-sized particles (quartz). We used our physical experiments ? where we could observe dynamics in real time ? to validate numerical models that the marine geoscience community uses to evaluate submarine slope failure in natural environments. Our assessment of flume-based observations and numerical-based predictions indicated that in some cases numerical models may overpredict slope stability when overpressure is present. Analyses of our benchtop experiments demonstrated that sediment cohesion is a key control for slope failure behavior, and higher cohesion results in more brittle failure behavior. For systems with 25% or less clay-sized particles (smectite or quartz), sediment permeability controlled the magnitude of overpressure required to induce slope failure. When clay-sized particle content was greater than 25%, permeability did not affect the overpressure required to induce failure. Additionally, for systems with greater than 25% cohesive clay-sized particles, repeat failure events were generated, and intact sediment blocks were rafted from the original sediment deposit. While blocks were produced, they were not mobilized downslope due to overpressure alone. Thus, we concluded that overpressure preconditions clay-rich slopes for blocky failures, but some external force is required to mobilize the blocks that could generate tsunamis. Our combined laboratory and numerical analyses showed that additional investigation of models used for submarine slope failure and tsunami hazard assessment is needed especially to identify what external forces will mobilize blocks that would generate tsunamis. We also demonstrate that local geology (clay content, surface and subsurface deformation) and hydrology (overpressure) need to be considered in hazard assessments to improve the accuracy of slope failure forecasts.

Extending these findings to failure potential and behavior of natural systems, we characterized the mechanical properties (shear strength, permeability, consolidation state, and overpressure) of submarine slope failure deposits and intact, unfailed sediments from the Japan Trench. We did this for samples from 10 sites collected by International Ocean Discovery Program Expedition 386: Japan Trench Paleoseismology. No lithological or mechanical trends were identified, and no correlation between failure potential and proximity to earthquakes was found suggesting that local heterogeneity is important for failure. Feedbacks between peak shear strength, overpressure, shear-weakening, and consolidation were identified indicating that once sediment remobilization begins, continued deformation reduces shear strength which increases failure potential.

Finally, we extended our study of physical experiments and natural observations to communication of risk assessment to coastal communities. We started working on improved communication through common language to express how geology and hydrology are critical for assessing failure likelihood and tsunamigenic potential. We focused on incorporating permeability, overpressure, cohesion, and regional seismic history in coastal community risk assessment, preparations, and response. Overpressures were identified as a critical mechanism for lowering slope stability and triggering failure. Clay concentrations were included as a key driver in failure behavior, including tsunamigenic potential, and potential for repeated localized failures. We then provided recommendations for modification of current assessment tools, including numerical models, to include these parameters, as they are often overlooked. We reinforced that the impact of these parameters is most important for margins not traditionally concerned with tsunamis.
